title: Exclusive: OpenAI Used Kenyan Workers on Less Than $2 Per Hour to Make ChatGPT Less Toxic

last_post.content:
People realise that:
- Training an AI model require workforce to label and classify stuff. It's not comes out of nowhere like magic.
- That work likely be subcontracted and not realized by tech startup itself.
- Sub-contractors will make it down in poor country because it's more affordable & profitable
- They will STILL pay MORE than the minimum wage, and include psychological support, which cost also less in those countries.
- It's the same with content moderation

https://time.com/6247678/openai-chatgpt-kenya-workers/

title: This Guy Noticed Jigsaw Puzzle Companies Use The Same Patterns, So He Made Some Mashups

last_post.content:
Tim Klein noticed that #jigsaw puzzle companies tend to use the same cut patterns for multiple puzzles. This makes the pieces interchangeable.” So he’s combined puzzles to create these amazingly bizarre hybrid images…

#art

https://themindcircle.com/jigsaw-puzzle-companies-use-the-same-patterns/

#ReleaseSunday Good things come to those who wait... After 10+ years, incl. 4+ years of release candidates and now prompted by a recent PR by @dimovich, earlier today I've released https://thi.ng/geom-clj v1.0.0 proper — a large, comprehensive #opensource 2D/3D geometry toolkit for both #Clojure & #ClojureScript. It's a massive project with too many features to list here, see readme & attached images for a partial list...

This was the first public project under the thi.ng moniker and from 2011-2016 I worked almost daily on it (though in it's current form it's the 4th rewrite). It also was the first project for which I decided to adapt a #LiterateProgramming process, using Emacs #OrgMode, allowing me to develop and intersperse source code with prose, sections, table of contents, reference/research links, tasks, diagrams, visualizations, tables & parametric code templates. Amazing productivity booster & dearly missed since... I continued using LP for several other large thi.ng libraries (most notably https://thi.ng/fabric), but in 2018 I decided to give up, since it proved to be a major hurdle for 3rd party contributions... 😢

In hindsight, the project, design and learnings from Clojure heavily inspired and directly expanded into my later (current!) #TypeScript work and the group of 20 new libraries under the same name (i.e. see https://thi.ng/geom). The latter is _not_ a direct port and currently still has a much stronger focus on 2D, yet again is one of the largest groups of libraries in the entire https://thi.ng/umbrella monorepo...

title: Pluralistic: Tiktok’s enshittification (21 Jan 2023) – Pluralistic: Daily links from Cory Doctorow

last_post.content:
Here is how #platforms die: first, they are good to their users; then they abuse their users to make things better for their business customers; finally, they abuse those business customers to claw back all the value for themselves. Then, they die.

If you'd like an essay-formatted version of this thread to read or share, here's a link to it on pluralistic.net, my surveillance-free, ad-free, tracker-free blog:

https://pluralistic.net/2023/01/21/potemkin-ai/#hey-guys

1/

title: Don’t Fall for the AI Hype w/ Timnit Gebru - Tech Won’t Save Us

last_post.content: I might sound like a broken record, but the newest episode of Tech Won't Save Us on AI hype with @parismarx and AI expert and former Google Ethical AI co-lead @timnitGebru is, again, incredibly enlightening. Most of the silicon valley AI vanity projects seem to be, at the moment, little more than unregulated theft and VC/M&A marketing material when they could be used for good instead of profit. Required listening, especially for tech journos. https://www.techwontsave.us/episode/151_dont_fall_for_the_ai_hype_w_timnit_gebru

title: CNET's AI Journalist Appears to Have Committed Extensive Plagiarism

last_post.content:
Investigation finds extensive evidence that AI used by CNET appears to have plagiarized the work of competitors and human writers at Bankrate and even CNET (Jon Christian/Futurism)

https://futurism.com/cnet-ai-plagiarism

title: Point of View: The biospheric emergency calls for scientists to change tactics

last_post.content:
This is *not* the way scientific papers typically begin:
_________________________

We are running out of time. Ecosystems across the planet are being destroyed at an accelerating rate. The life sciences – once a field dedicated to the study of living systems and our interactions with them – are increasingly becoming sciences of the dead. Up to one million species are currently threatened with extinction, many of them within decades.
_________________________

It's a very good sign, however, an indication that at least some scientists are now ready to speak boldly and unequivocally about the greatest emergency our species has ever faced.

SEE THE FULL PAPER -- https://elifesciences.org/articles/83292

#ClimateEmergency #BiodiversityLoss #Extinction

Just under 34,000 earthquakes in Iceland which occurred in the year 2022. Silly way to show serious data, but seeing that super beautiful DEM data for Iceland, I couldn't resist.

Initial data-vis inspiration: mastodon.social/@ragnarheidar

Map DEM: Based on data from
National Land Survey of Iceland

Earthquake data: https://skjalftalisa.vedur.is/#/page/map

Wanted to do more with this concept but have to switch gears for a few days. Hope to revisit it shortly.

#houdini #datavis #datavisualization

OK this is actually pretty incredible.

The Smithsonian making 4 million digital items public domain. CC0 means you don't need to give attribution, there's no copyright to worry about, no restrictions on using them in photoshops etc.

It's a huge move for open media for such a big name to be making such a large collection open like this. It's the kind of thing I never really thought we would see start to happen.

https://www.si.edu/openaccess/

title: Thoughts on the Python packaging ecosystem

last_post.content:
I read this post on the current state of Python packaging with great interest because it's from someone who really understands and spends a lot of time in the Python open source/packaging ecosystem.

In all the time I've spend developing Python, a good 40%+ of my developer time has been spent trying to figure out how to ship and check code instead of writing it. There's no one easy solution, but maybe we could start with pip.

https://pradyunsg.me/blog/2023/01/21/thoughts-on-python-packaging/

#NerdHumor #Statistics

https://xkcd.com/2726/

Here’s one of my favourite artefacts: an ancient amber bear. Carved some 10,000 years ago, it washed up on a beach at Fanø in Denmark, from a submerged Mesolithic settlement.
On display National Museum of Denmark, Copenhagen. Read more about amber from submerged settlements: https://en.natmus.dk/historical-knowledge/denmark/prehistoric-period-until-1050-ad/the-mesolithic-period/magical-amber-animals/amber-from-submerged-settlements/

#Archaeology
#Art

title: Trove's funding runs out in July 2023 – and the National Library is threatening to pull the plug. It's time for a radical overhaul

last_post.content:
My thoughts on the parlous state of cultural institution funding made it to commercial weekend TV last weekend when Channel 7 did a short piece on the uncertain future of the National Library of Australia's Trove service. You can see the full story here: https://7news.com.au/video/sunrise/national-treasure-at-risk-bc-6319059142112

Based on the article written with @mikejones in The Conversation: https://theconversation.com/troves-funding-runs-out-in-july-2023-and-the-national-library-is-threatening-to-pull-the-plug-its-time-for-a-radical-overhaul-197025

#Trove #libraries #funding

title: Pickup trucks have gotten bigger, higher-tech — and more dangerous

last_post.content: Love this Axios Visuals look at the evolution of pickup trucks and their popularity in the US (and how they are used for shopping / daily driving much more than hauling boulders) . This view of the inversion of the ratio between cab and cargo bed tells the story. https://www.axios.com/ford-pickup-trucks-history

The Sleeper Train renaissance in Europe continues!

Austrian state company ÖBB used old Deutsche Bahn rolling stock for its NightJet service—now its popularity has led them to commission new trains of their own. Here's a map of planned routes for 2024:

https://derklimablog.de/mobilitaet/die-fantastische-renaissance-der-nachtzuege/

#Python devs: if you're writing test cases that involve date/time values, `freezegun` is a very useful package that lets you "freeze" time so you can write repeatable tests.

https://pypi.org/project/freezegun/

What. A. Day. No power (and the replacement generator install is a few weeks away). No Comcast biz internet. VZ 5G/LTE was 100% useless all day. Now shunting the fam to a warm & cozy place to hunker down for the eve.

BUT! I managed to crank out a Drop in the wee AM hours (before VZ inet died)!

Drop #184 (2023-01-23): Belated Lunar New Year Edition

- 🐰 RabbitControl; (UI for meatspace)
- 🐇 Rabbit Ear; (computational origami!)
- 🐱 tac (just what it looks like)

https://dailyfinds.hrbrmstr.dev/p/drop-184-2023-01-23-belated-lunar

title: ChatGPT is now writing legislation. Is this the future?

last_post.content: A lawmaker asked ChatGPT to help him draft a bill to regulate ChatGPT. File under: What could go wrong? https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/2023/01/23/chatgpt-is-now-writing-legislation-is-this-future/

title: Promoters of Election Lies Also Hyped a Hospital for Ukraine. That Never Happened Either.

last_post.content:
True the Vote, a group that spread discredited election conspiracy theories, “abandoned” The Freedom Hospital in April 2022, according to its lawyers. Yet board member Gregg Phillips continued to seek donations for the project for months afterward.

https://www.propublica.org/article/ukraine-freedom-hospital-true-the-vote-phillips-engelbrecht
